Message.Msg: I began buying in the $10's and bought repeatedly at regularly spaced prices down into the $8's as the share price dropped. All I ask is to be left in peace to hold the shares as a long-term investment and not to have them forcibly wrested from me at a price at which I never had any intention of selling. I would prefer to keep my shares in a Dell "gone dark" with the SEC.

Message.Title: Hate Business leaders like Michael Dell.
Message.Msg: The future of PC is Mobile Computing. The computer industry is not at the end of its growth, it's actually entering a whole new phase. Along with mobile communications, the next phase in the computer industry will be to move towards mobile computing for day-to-day work and interactions. Apps were stuff from yesterday. Apple dominated the apps market in recent years. Apps is today, mobile computing and services that really enhance life is the future. Dell obviously failed to keep up as a technology company by not getting into mobile. In the process of making personal wealth Michael Dell let the company slide and shareholders suffer big time. NOW he want to go private to create mobile devices for computing, communication, and provide services. The question is WHY COULDN'T HE DO INNOVATIONS AT DELL? The answers could only be greed, making personal wealth, not paying attention to the company and not caring for shareholders. HATE business leaders like that. The board must not approve the sale before sucking every last penny from Michel Dell. Sale price should be minimum double or no deal.

Topic.Title: Hate Business leaders like Michael Dell.

Message.Msg: SPAM!!!!

Message.Title: Share price very low,,, high teens to 20 ..
Message.Msg: "I don't think an LBO would get much support at $15 a share," says Richard Pzena, the founder and chief investment officer of Pzena Investment Management, which holds 14 million Dell shares on Sept. 30. Pzena says his firm's analysis suggests Dell is worth $25 share. "We might think about supporting an LBO at $20, but at $15, we think an LBO would amount to insiders trying to steal the company because of current market conditions." Those conditions—notably weak earnings—drove Dell stock below $10 late last year and reflect decisions made by Michael Dell.
link?

Message.Title: LBO share price...
Message.Msg: DELL'S SHAREHOLDER BASE IS dominated by value investors like Dodge & Cox and Southeastern Asset Management, some of which bought their stakes at higher prices. Dell traded at $17 a year ago. Bernstein analyst Toni Sacconaghi wrote that the "simple math" suggests that a Dell LBO probably would get shareholder approval because of the combination of Michael Dell's 15% holding, takeover arbitrageurs, and index funds. Takeover arbs rarely oppose deals, and the same is true for indexers, who may hold 8% of Dell. Southeastern's stance likely will be critical, since it held a 7.5% stake on Sept. 30 (the most recent reporting date), second behind Michael Dell. If Southeastern backs the deal, it will be very tough to stop. Yet there's a good chance that Southeastern opposes an LBO because it stated in the third-quarter commentary for its Longleaf funds that Dell is worth at least $20 per share, and it has a history of activism. If Southeastern opposes the LBO, it likely would get support from existing holders. Let's see if noted activists like Dan Loeb, Bill Ackman, or Carl Icahn take stakes in Dell and work to kill any deal, or push for a higher price. Dell, Silver Lake, and Southeastern wouldn't comment.

At a price of $12 to $14 there is zero reason to be in the stock at this time when you couple it with a 50-50 chance of getting done anyway.No risk-reward...............I was in Dell the last 3 days just for a short trade, bought 3000 at $13.04 and sold 30 of the calls at 13 strike for .27 which expired Friday and got called away.
So ... if Southeastern's gets least $20 per share, it will quietly accept the LBO deal.

Another purpose of these: "multiple unnamed sources", "sources with knowledge of the matter", and only reliable sides were saying "was unable to comment". Others were providing pure speculation "what if" = is to float a price publicly that maybe a way to test the reaction of major shareholders to the deal price range. Of course the major advantage is to allow many peripheral insiders, their clients, their friends and relatives etc. on the deal, at investment banking houses, legal houses, etc to buy Dell stock legally for their accounts, without running afoul of SEC insider trading rules.
